https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/48210/ : SUCCESS

I want to break this into at least 2 parts:

1) reliably detect the hwmon service(s) on/offline

[optional 1.5] - extract the mangled-name of the hwmon service, right now it's hard-coded

2) incorporate (1) into starting fan-monitor, under happy path as well as the sighup handler

I expect this to go into 2-3 commits.

First one detects service names and registers a callback. Second will detect poweroff state and safely wait. Third will handle chassison state (fill in callback to handle service going offline).
what's the reason you're looking for more than just the Sensor.Value interface?
To handle the services hosting the configured target interface(s) which may or may not be the same as the services hosting the Sensor.Value interface.
If GetSubTree returned the service, then it will be running, so I'm not sure this NameHasOwner call is necessary?
I think its possible to have a race condition where the service goes down but doesn't get updated in D-Bus quickly enough. lets get Matt B's opinion.

From looking at where the getSubTreeRaw call is to where these hwmon matches are created, I dont see why this couldnt be moved up within the getSubTreeRaw loop instead of pushing service names on a list and then loop that list here to register the matches. If the hwmon match subscriptions can be moved up to replace lines 174-177 then there's no need to check nameHasOwner.

Please point out the reason for not having this just included in the getSubTreeRaw loop above on line 154 and we can re-address this comment.

I was able to refactor it into the original loop. To address Spinler's comment, the time between when the Fan obj is created (and thus where its service(s) are stored) vs when this startup code is called can be arbitrarily long, so it makes sense to check that the service is actually running.
Could you add an @return here to desribe what the bool indicates?

So I stopped reviewing this after getting a feeling these changes are already basically done utilizing the `subscribeSensorsToServices` method? Or can these changes re-use much of what's already done there?
nameOwnerChanged signals report the state of the service in the message given to the callback.
? There's no reason to have this method.
used in the next commit. this commit just establishes that callbacks work properly. It was tested with debug code to prove it is called at the right time.
This isnt specific to being a "hwmon" match.. its just a unique_ptr to a match object.
Appears this entire method is unnecessary from its definition
it's used in a the subsequent commit.

I dont believe this bool is necessary on setting up the match objects since those are setup based on the service name found and if no service name was found for a sensor, it should fail then to subscribe the callback.
the return value is used in the next commit to activate re-triggering.
